The guidance, which is aimed at public health professionals managing people with COVID-19 in home care and isolation who have pets or other animals, warns that animals can contract and transmit the virus to humans. According to the CDC, there have been several cases of pets and other animals, including service or working animals, testing positive for COVID-19 after being exposed to the virus by their owners. The agency recommends that pet owners who have COVID-19 should avoid contact with their animals and have someone else take care of them until they are no longer contagious. In addition, the CDC advises pet owners to practice good hygiene, including washing their hands before and after handling their pets, avoiding kissing or cuddling with them, and wearing a mask while interacting with them. The agency also recommends that pets be kept indoors and away from other animals and people outside the household. While the risk of transmission from animals to humans is low, the CDC warns that it is still possible and that precautions should be taken to protect both pets and their owners. The agency is continuing to monitor the situation and provide updates as new information becomes available.

This year, the commemoration is even more significant as the world faces a new and more potent strain of the bacterium. According to recent reports, the new strain, which has been dubbed "Super-TB," is more infectious and deadlier than any other strain of the disease. Super-TB is believed to have originated in China, where it has already claimed the lives of thousands of people. The situation is so dire that the Chinese government has declared a state of emergency and is working with the World Health Organization (WHO) to contain the outbreak. Experts warn that Super-TB is highly contagious and can be transmitted through the air, making it difficult to contain. It can also be contracted by touching contaminated surfaces or coming into contact with infected bodily fluids. The symptoms of Super-TB are similar to those of regular TB, but they are more severe and can lead to death within days. The disease is resistant to most antibiotics, making it difficult to treat. The WHO has called for urgent action to contain the outbreak and prevent the spread of Super-TB. They have urged governments and health organizations to step up efforts to diagnose and treat the disease. As the world commemorates World TB Day, it is clear that the fight against TB is far from over. With the emergence of Super-TB, it is more important than ever to raise public awareness about the disease and to step up efforts to end the global TB epidemic.

This new revelation has caused widespread panic among phone users, with many wondering if they should abandon their devices altogether. However, experts are recommending a more measured approach. They suggest limiting phone usage to no more than 15 minutes at a time, and taking frequent breaks to rest the throat. In addition to limiting phone usage, there are several other remedies that can help soothe a sore throat. Gargling with warm salt water, drinking honey and lemon tea, and using throat lozenges are all effective ways to reduce pain and inflammation. It's important to note that while smartphone use may be a contributing factor to sore throats, it's still important to rule out other potential causes. Viral and bacterial infections, allergies, and irritants can all lead to sore throats, so it's important to seek medical advice if symptoms persist for more than a week. Furthermore, the report stresses the importance of washing hands thoroughly and frequently during the repair process. Many Americans have expressed concern about the safety of scheduling repairs and services in their homes. However, the CDC's report offers some hope. By following these simple precautions, homeowners can reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission and keep their homes safe and healthy.
